Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Story: I was walking home with my younger brother, my phone buzzing in my pocket with a message from my mentor. She wanted an update on the project, but I’d hit a wall with the new software and didn’t know how to move forward. I knew she expected me to reach out as soon as I ran into trouble, but I kept hesitating, not wanting to seem incapable. As I typed and erased my message for the third time, I noticed my brother drifting ahead, earbuds in, eyes glued to his screen. He stepped off the curb, not even glancing at the traffic. My heart lurched. I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe. But my mentor’s message blinked insistently, reminding me of my responsibility to communicate. I felt torn, caught between shouting for my brother and finally admitting my struggle to my mentor. Both roles demanded my attention at the exact same moment, and I could feel the pressure building, unsure which responsibility to answer first.
